text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

RANJAY GULATI: The fifth and
final T is transformation.

If you look at some
of these great coaches

and if you talk to some of their
players, they will tell you

they have truly
transformed by them.
I'll start with Pete Carroll.

Pete talks about coaching
up, that every human being

needs to be coached, coached
to really recenter themselves

about who am I as a human
being, not as a player.
Who am I as a human being?
Why am I here?
What's my purpose in life?

And it's only when we connect
into our own sense of life

purpose and find a
way to then connect

what I'm doing in my work
with my life purpose,
I can truly elevate myself.

The starting point
for this is really
a place of caring and trust.

It's only when these
people, the players,

feel that this person cares
about me and I can trust them,
they have my back.

But at the same time that
there is caring and trust,
there is also challenge.
Am I being pushed?

Now, remember, if you're only
challenging and not supporting,
you're a demanding boss.

If you're only supporting
and not challenging,

you're the unconditional
lovey-dovey boss.

It's the ability to say,
I'm going to challenge you
while I support you.

And that's the mastery of
some of these great coaches.

Let me give you an example
right here from our backyard.

Mike Way, the coach of
the men's squash team here

at Harvard and Kathy
Delaney-Smith, the coach

of the women's basketball
team, retired now,

I had a chance to
talk to players who
played for both these coaches.

Each of them was described to
me as a transformational coach,

a coach who made them better,
better players, better
human beings.

The lessons they learned
from those coaches

stayed with the players long
after they were no longer
playing for that coach.

And if you look at what Mike
does and what Kathy did,

they are masters
of understanding

how to provide intense
support to the player

while also challenging
them to do better.

When you talk about
transformation,

you also dial into connecting
them to their larger

purpose in life
to understand, how

do I put what I'm doing
in the context of my life?

To help somebody
do that, you have

to have the curiosity
and interest

to want to know that
person beyond a worker bee
to do their job.

It's the ability to
engage with that person
as a whole human being.

In a case I wrote
on the Seahawks,

Pete Carroll coaches
Marshawn Lynch,

who is considered uncoachable
by a lot of other teams.

He says to Marshawn, I
want you to be Marshawn.

I'm not going to
try to change you.
But I want to support you.
He tries to understand Marshawn.

Now, Marshawn has some
family constraints.

He says, I'm going
to help you there,

but I also expect
more of you, Marshawn.

And so one of the anecdotes
was how Marshawn couldn't
come to practice on time.

And he said, I
can't do it myself.

My uncle always has
been in my life.

And he would always help me get
organized, and I can't do it.

He says, well,
where's your uncle?
He's in Oakland.
And he's unemployed.

He says, well, let's
hire him in the Seahawks.

And he became the groundskeeper
of the Seahawks grounds.
Marshawn was on time ever since.

So it's only when you understand
the whole self of a person

that you are able to coach
up and really support them
while challenge them.

You can't challenge
if they don't trust
and you feel supported by you.

Now, let's think about this in
the business of organization

as we think about
how we can not only

help people elevate their
performance in the workplace,

but also live their whole
life's full potential.

How do we help them
feel truly transformed

and ask ourselves how
will they show up at work

when we have those
transformed people?

I think sometimes what
happens to leadership

is we fall into the bucket
of either a demanding model
or a supporting model.

It feels almost
contradictory mixed messages

to learn to challenge and
support at the same time,

yet when you do, you truly
know how to transform people.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
